message.content:
<<<api>>>: BufferedReader.readLine
<<<code>>>: 
```java
public RecordManager(){
    int pos;
    String athlete, record, country, raceTime;
    try {
        BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("resultdata.txt"));
        String line = reader.readLine();
        while(line != null){
            Scanner sc = new Scanner(line).useDelimiter("#");
            athlete = sc.next();
            country = sc.next();
            pos = sc.nextInt();
            record = sc.next();
            raceTime = sc.next();
            sc.close();
            if("WRC".equals(record)){
                resultArr[size] = new WorldRecord(athlete, country, pos, raceTime);
            }
            else if("OLR".equals(record)){
                resultArr[size] = new OlympicRecord(athlete, country, pos, raceTime);
            }
            else{
                resultArr[size] = new RaceResult(athlete, country, pos, raceTime);
            }
            size++;
            line = reader.readLine();
        }
    } catch (FileNotFoundException ex) {
        Logger.getLogger(RecordManager.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);
    } catch (IOException ex) {
        Logger.getLogger(RecordManager.class.getName()).log(Level.SEVERE, null, ex);
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: The issue with your code is that you are using `Scanner.next()` which reads the input until the space is found. In your case, you are trying to read a line from a file where data is separated by '#'. So, when it tries to read beyond the available tokens in a line, it throws `NoSuchElementException`. 

To fix this, you can use `BufferedReader.readLine()` which reads a line of text. A line is considered to be terminated by any one of a line feed ('\n'), a carriage return ('\r'), or a carriage return followed immediately by a linefeed. This will ensure that you are reading the entire line of data, and then you can use a `Scanner` to parse each line separately.
